results.title: The Dawns here are quiet = A Zori Zdes Tikhiye
results.creator_credit: Stanislav Rostotsky, G Natanson and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Set in WW2, Karelia, northwest Russia, this elegiac war drama is about a small group of female soldiers in training, who are unexpectedly called upon to face a Nazi patrol of paratroopers. The narrative sensitively portrays the women’s camaraderie, as well as their pre-war domestic life, and spousal relationships. A fine ensemble cast heads what is widely regarded as powerful statement about war and society, and the sacrifices of ordinary citizens made in extraordinary times. Based on a true story and adapted from the book by Boris Vasilyev. Also known as “At Dawn its quiet here” and “That Dawn should be peaceful”.

results.title: Other People's Money
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Part Three of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, explains that without the Hollywood studios’ money independent producers had to find backers. This program includes interviews with top Australian producers.

results.title: They fought for their motherland = Oni srazhalis za rodinu
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Epic film by Soviet filmmaker Sergei Bondarchuk, depicts the skirmishes faced by Russian troops, during the WW2 invasion of Stalingrad by the Germans. Impressive action sequences meticulously recreate the drama, danger, destruction and disorientation of war. Winner of the State Prize of the Russian Federation, 1977.

results.title: Bette Davis' eyes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
What makes a star? Clips from a host of films look at the legendary stars - Sarah Bernhardt, Shirley Temple, Joan Crawford, Errol Flynn and Bette Davis. This program is episode seven in the ten part documentary, “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: The Cranes are flying = Letyat Zhuravli
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Expressionistic melodrama set in WW2, about a young Russian woman, who believes her lover to have perished in battle. Devastated by grief she falls into a passionless affair with his cousin, who seduces her during an air-raid. Struggling to find meaning amid the tragedies that have befallen her and the calamity of war, she vacillates between despair and hope. Winner of the Palm d’or at Cannes. Stars Tatyana Samoylova in the title role.

results.title: Filmstruck Series
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Going It Alone
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filmmaking has never really been studio based. John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, interviews some of the independents. He also takes a look at the Disney animation studio in Burbank, as well as showing us rare footage of a surrealist “Snow White” starring Betty Boop. this program is the final episode in the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: The Best Remaining Seats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
John Baxter, well known Australian historian and cinema critic, examines the fall of the great cinema houses, how the Hollywood industry built them and Hollywood acted as a magnet for both talent and money. Charlie Chaplin’s career is also analysed. This episode is one of the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Switzerland/Texas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filming in Australia has been described as “Switzerland wanting to go to Texas”. In this program, John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the state of the Australian film industry. This is part five of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck” which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.
